title: Get started with giscoR
text: Full site examples vignettes https://ropengov.github.io/giscoR/ giscoR package designed provide simple interface GISCO API. Within Eurostat, GISCO meets European Commission’s geographical information needs three levels: European Union, member countries, regions. GISCO provides shapefiles different formats, focusing especially European Union also offering worldwide datasets country polygons, labels, borders, coastlines. GISCO supplies data multiple resolutions: high-detail datasets small areas (01M, 03M) lightweight datasets larger areas (10M, 20M, 60M). Datasets available three projections: EPSG:4326, EPSG:3035, EPSG:3857. giscoR returns sf objects; see https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/ details.

title: Get started with giscoR
text: giscoR supports caching downloaded datasets. Set cache directory : file available locally, downloaded directory subsequent requests data load local cache. experience problems downloading, can also manually download file GISCO API website store local cache directory.
code: gisco_set_cache_dir("./path/to/location")

title: Get started with giscoR
text: Please note following attribution licensing requirements using GISCO data: Eurostat’s general copyright notice licence policy applies. Moreover, specific rules apply following datasets available downloading. download use data subject rules accepted. See administrative units statistical units details. Source: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata function, gisco_attributions(), provides guidance topic returns attributions several languages.
code: library(giscoR) c(   gisco_attributions(lang = "en"),   gisco_attributions(lang = "fr"),   gisco_attributions(lang = "de") ) |> cat(sep = "\n\n") #> © EuroGeographics for the administrative boundaries #>  #> © EuroGeographics pour les limites administratives #>  #> © EuroGeographics bezüglich der Verwaltungsgrenzen

title: Get started with giscoR
text: Examples downloading data: Plot Asia per UN M49 Standard: Political map Asia (UN M49) can select specific countries name (language), ISO3 codes, Eurostat codes. However, mix identifier types single call. can also combine different datasets — set resolution epsg (optionally year) value: Political map North Africa
code: library(sf) library(ggplot2) # Use ggplot for plotting  asia <- gisco_get_countries(region = "Asia") world <- gisco_get_countries()  ggplot(world) +   geom_sf(fill = "#DFDFDF", color = "#656565") +   geom_sf(data = asia, fill = "#FDFBEA", color = "#656565") +   coord_sf(crs = "+proj=laea +lon_0=95 +lat_0=35") +   lims(     x = c(-5000000, 7000000),     y = c(-5000000, 3000000)   ) +   theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#C7E7FB")) +   labs(     title = "Asia",     subtitle = "UN M49 Standard",     caption = gisco_attributions()   ) cntr <- c("Morocco", "Algeria", "Tunisia", "Libya", "Egypt")  africa_north <- gisco_get_countries(   country = cntr,   resolution = "03",   epsg = "4326", year = "2024" )  # For ordering the plot  africa_north$NAME_ENGL <- factor(africa_north$NAME_ENGL, levels = cntr) # Coastlines  coast <- gisco_get_coastal_lines(   resolution = "03",   epsg = "4326",   year = "2016" )  # Plot ggplot(coast) +   geom_sf(color = "#B9B9B9") +   geom_sf(data = africa_north, fill = "#346733", color = "#335033") +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-13, 37), ylim = c(18.5, 40)) +   facet_wrap(vars(NAME_ENGL), ncol = 2) +   labs(caption = gisco_attributions("fr"))

title: Get started with giscoR
text: example shows giscoR can used together Eurostat data. plotting use ggplot2; however, package supports sf objects (e.g., tmap, mapsf, leaflet) can used. Disposable income private households NUTS 2 regions (2022)
code: # EU members library(giscoR) library(dplyr) library(eurostat) library(ggplot2)  nuts2 <- gisco_get_nuts(   year = "2021", epsg = "3035", resolution = "10",   nuts_level = "2" ) # Borders from countries borders <- gisco_get_countries(epsg = "3035", year = "2020", resolution = "3")  eu_bord <- borders |>   filter(CNTR_ID %in% nuts2$CNTR_CODE)  # Eurostat data - Disposable income pps <- get_eurostat("tgs00026") |>   filter(TIME_PERIOD == "2022-01-01")  nuts2_sf <- nuts2 |>   left_join(pps, by = "geo") |>   mutate(     values_th = values / 1000,     categ = cut(values_th, c(0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, Inf))   )   # Adjust the labels labs <- levels(nuts2_sf$categ) labs[1] <- "< 15" labs[6] <- "> 120" levels(nuts2_sf$categ) <- labs   # Finally the plot ggplot(nuts2_sf) +   # Background   geom_sf(data = borders, fill = "#e1e1e1", color = NA) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = categ), color = "grey20", linewidth = .1) +   geom_sf(data = eu_bord, fill = NA, color = "black", linewidth = .15) +   # Center in Europe: EPSG 3035   coord_sf(xlim = c(2377294, 6500000), ylim = c(1413597, 5228510)) +   # Legends and color   scale_fill_manual(     values = hcl.colors(length(labs), "Geyser", rev = TRUE),     # Label NA     labels = function(x) {       ifelse(is.na(x), "No Data", x)     },     na.value = "#e1e1e1"   ) +   guides(fill = guide_legend(nrow = 1)) +   theme_void() +   theme(     text = element_text(colour = "grey0"),     panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#97dbf2"),     panel.border = element_rect(fill = NA, color = "grey10"),     plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, vjust = -1, size = 12),     plot.subtitle = element_text(       hjust = 0.5, vjust = -2, face = "bold",       margin = margin(b = 10, t = 5), size = 12     ),     plot.caption = element_text(       size = 8, hjust = 0, margin =         margin(b = 4, t = 8)     ),     legend.text = element_text(size = 7, ),     legend.title = element_text(size = 7),     legend.position = "bottom",     legend.direction = "horizontal",     legend.text.position = "bottom",     legend.title.position = "top",     legend.key.height = rel(0.5),     legend.key.width = unit(.1, "npc")   ) +   # Annotate and labels   labs(     title = "Disposable income of private households (2022)",     subtitle = "NUTS-2 level",     fill = "euros (thousands)",     caption = paste0(       "Source: Eurostat, ", gisco_attributions()     )   )

title: giscoR | R package for download geodata from GISCO - Eurostat
text: giscoR R package provides simple interface GISCO data Eurostat. allows download work global European geospatial datasets — country boundaries, NUTS regions, coastlines, labels — directly R.

title: giscoR | R package for download geodata from GISCO - Eurostat
text: Retrieve GISCO files countries, regions, administrative units. Access data multiple resolutions: 60M, 20M, 10M, 03M, 01M. Choose three projections: EPSG 4326, 3035, 3857. Works seamlessly sf objects spatial analysis. Includes caching faster repeated access.

code: install.packages("giscoR") # install.packages("pak")  pak::pak("rOpenGov/giscoR") install.packages("giscoR", repos = c("https://ropengov.r-universe.dev", "https://cloud.r-project.org"))

title: giscoR | R package for download geodata from GISCO - Eurostat
text: script highlights features giscoR :
code: library(giscoR) library(sf) library(dplyr)  # Download The Netherlands boundaries at different resolutions nl_all <- lapply(c("60", "20", "10", "03"), function(r) {   gisco_get_countries(country = "Netherlands", year = 2024, resolution = r) |>     mutate(res = paste0(r, "M")) }) |>   bind_rows()  glimpse(nl_all) #> Rows: 4 #> Columns: 13 #> $ CNTR_ID   <chr> "NL", "NL", "NL", "NL" #> $ CNTR_NAME <chr> "Nederland", "Nederland", "Nederland", "Nederland" #> $ NAME_ENGL <chr> "Netherlands", "Netherlands", "Netherlands", "Netherlands" #> $ NAME_FREN <chr> "Pays-Bas", "Pays-Bas", "Pays-Bas", "Pays-Bas" #> $ ISO3_CODE <chr> "NLD", "NLD", "NLD", "NLD" #> $ SVRG_UN   <chr> "UN Member State", "UN Member State", "UN Member State", "UN… #> $ CAPT      <chr> "Amsterdam", "Amsterdam", "Amsterdam", "Amsterdam" #> $ EU_STAT   <chr> "T", "T", "T", "T" #> $ EFTA_STAT <chr> "F", "F", "F", "F" #> $ CC_STAT   <chr> "F", "F", "F", "F" #> $ NAME_GERM <chr> "Niederlande", "Niederlande", "Niederlande", "Niederlande" #> $ geometry  <MULTIPOLYGON [°]> MULTIPOLYGON (((7.208935 53..., MULTIPOLYGON (((7.202794 53.… #> $ res       <chr> "60M", "20M", "10M", "03M"  # Plot with ggplot2  library(ggplot2)  ggplot(nl_all) +   geom_sf(fill = "#AD1D25") +   facet_wrap(~res) +   labs(     title = "The Netherlands boundaries at different resolutions",     subtitle = "Year: 2024",     caption = gisco_attributions()   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: giscoR | R package for download geodata from GISCO - Eurostat
text: example shows thematic map created ggplot2 package. data obtained via eurostat package. follows approach presented Milos Popovic post. start extracting corresponding geographic data: now download data Eurostat: Finally, merge manipulate data create final plot:
code: library(giscoR) library(dplyr) library(eurostat) library(ggplot2)  # Get sf objects nuts3 <- gisco_get_nuts(   year = 2021,   epsg = 3035,   resolution = 10,   nuts_level = 3 )  # Get country lines (NUTS 0 level)  country_lines <- gisco_get_nuts(   year = 2021,   epsg = 3035,   resolution = 10,   spatialtype = "BN",   nuts_level = 0 ) # Use eurostat popdens <- get_eurostat("demo_r_d3dens") |>   filter(TIME_PERIOD == "2021-01-01") # Merge data nuts3_sf <- nuts3 |>   left_join(popdens, by = "geo")  # Breaks and labels br <- c(0, 25, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2500, 5000, 10000, 30000) labs <- prettyNum(br[-1], big.mark = ",")  # Label function used in the plot, mainly for NAs labeller_plot <- function(x) {   ifelse(is.na(x), "No Data", x) } nuts3_sf <- nuts3_sf |>   # Cut with labels   mutate(values_cut = cut(values, br, labels = labs))   # Palette pal <- hcl.colors(length(labs), "Lajolla")   # Plot ggplot(nuts3_sf) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = values_cut), linewidth = 0, color = NA, alpha = 0.9) +   geom_sf(data = country_lines, col = "black", linewidth = 0.1) +   # Center in Europe: EPSG 3035   coord_sf(     xlim = c(2377294, 7453440),     ylim = c(1313597, 5628510)   ) +   # Legends   scale_fill_manual(     values = pal,     # Label for NA     labels = labeller_plot,     drop = FALSE, guide = guide_legend(direction = "horizontal", nrow = 1)   ) +   # Theming   theme_void() +   # Theme   theme(     plot.title = element_text(       color = rev(pal)[2], size = rel(1.5),       hjust = 0.5, vjust = -6     ),     plot.subtitle = element_text(       color = rev(pal)[2], size = rel(1.25),       hjust = 0.5, vjust = -10, face = "bold"     ),     plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey60", hjust = 0.5, vjust = 0),     legend.text = element_text(color = "grey20", hjust = .5),     legend.title = element_text(color = "grey20", hjust = .5),     legend.position = "bottom",     legend.title.position = "top",     legend.text.position = "bottom",     legend.key.height = unit(.5, "line"),     legend.key.width = unit(2.5, "line")   ) +   # Annotate and labs   labs(     title = "Population density in 2021",     subtitle = "NUTS-3 level",     fill = "people per sq. kilometer",     caption = paste0(       "Source: Eurostat, ", gisco_attributions(),       "\nBased on Milos Popovic: ",       "https://milospopovic.net/how-to-make-choropleth-map-in-r/"     )   )

title: GISCO Address API — gisco_address_api
text: country Country code (country = "LU"). province province within country. list provinces within certain country use provinces endpoint (gisco_address_api_provinces(country = "LU")). city city within province. list cities within certain province use cities endpoint (gisco_address_api_cities(province = "capellen")). road road within city. housenumber house number house name within road street. postcode Can used combination previous arguments. verbose logical. TRUE displays informational messages. x, y x y coordinates (longitude latitude) converted human-readable address.

title: GISCO API bulk download — gisco_bulk_download
text: id character string number. Type dataset downloaded, see Details. Values supported : "countries" "coastal_lines" "communes" "lau" "nuts" "urban_audit" "postal_codes" argument replaces previous (deprecated) argument id_giscoR. year character string number. Release year file, see Details. cache_dir character string. path cache directory. See Caching strategies section gisco_set_cache_dir(). update_cache logical. cached file refreshed?. Default FALSE. set TRUE force new download. verbose logical. TRUE displays informational messages. resolution character string number. Resolution geospatial data. One : "60": 1:60 million. "20": 1:20 million. "10": 1:10 million. "03": 1:3 million. "01": 1:1 million. ext Extension file(s) downloaded. Formats available "shp", "geojson", "svg", "json", "gdb". See Details. recursive recursive longer supported; function never perform recursive extraction child .zip files. case "shp.zip inside top-level .zip, unzipped. ... Ignored. argument id_giscoR () captured via ... re-directed id warning.

See years available corresponding functions: gisco_get_countries(). gisco_get_coastal_lines(). gisco_get_communes(). gisco_get_lau(). gisco_get_nuts(). gisco_get_urban_audit(). gisco_get_postal_codes(). usual extensions used across giscoR "gpkg" "shp", however formats already available GISCO. Note performing bulk download may need adjust default "ext" value corresponding function connect downloaded files (see Examples).

title: Grid dataset — gisco_get_grid
code: grid <- gisco_get_grid(resolution = 20)  # If downloaded correctly proceed  if (!is.null(grid)) {   library(dplyr)    grid <- grid |>     mutate(popdens = TOT_P_2021 / 20)    breaks <- c(0, 0.1, 100, 500, 1000, 5000, 10000, Inf)    # Cut groups   grid <- grid |>     mutate(popdens_cut = cut(popdens,       breaks = breaks,       include.lowest = TRUE     ))    cut_labs <- prettyNum(breaks, big.mark = " ")[-1]   cut_labs[1] <- "0"   cut_labs[7] <- "> 10 000"    pal <- c("black", hcl.colors(length(breaks) - 2,     palette = "Spectral",     alpha = 0.9   ))    library(ggplot2)    ggplot(grid) +     geom_sf(aes(fill = popdens_cut), color = NA, linewidth = 0) +     coord_sf(       xlim = c(2500000, 7000000),       ylim = c(1500000, 5200000)     ) +     scale_fill_manual(       values = pal, na.value = "black",       name = "people per sq. kilometer",       labels = cut_labs,       guide = guide_legend(         direction = "horizontal",         nrow = 1       )     ) +     theme_void() +     labs(       title = "Population density in Europe",       subtitle = "Grid: 20 km.",       caption = gisco_attributions()     ) +     theme(       text = element_text(colour = "white"),       plot.background = element_rect(fill = "grey2"),       plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),       plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),       plot.caption = element_text(         color = "grey60", hjust = 0.5, vjust = 0,         margin = margin(t = 5, b = 10)       ),       legend.position = "bottom",       legend.title.position = "top",       legend.text.position = "bottom",       legend.key.height = unit(0.5, "lines"),       legend.key.width = unit(1, "lines")     ) }

title: Local Administrative Units (LAU) dataset — gisco_get_lau
text: Nomenclature Territorial Units Statistics (NUTS) LAU nomenclature hierarchical classifications statistical regions together subdivide EU economic territory regions five different levels (NUTS 1, 2 3 LAU , respectively, moving larger smaller territorial units). LAU classification covered legislative act. Geographical extent covers European Union, EFTA countries, candidate countries. scale dataset 1:100 000. data contains National Statistical agency LAU code can joined LAU lists well field GISCO_ID unique identifier consisting Country code LAU code. Total resident population figures (31 December) also added ins versions based associated LAU lists

what: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
text: GISCO statistical unit dataset represents NUTS (nomenclature territorial units statistics) statistical regions means multipart polygon, polyline point topology. NUTS geographical information completed attribute tables set cartographic help lines better visualise multipart polygonal regions. NUTS hierarchical system divided 3 levels: NUTS 1: major socio-economic regions NUTS 2: basic regions application regional policies NUTS 3: small regions specific diagnoses. Also, NUTS 0 level, usually corresponds national boundaries.

title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
code: gisco_get_nuts(   year = 2024,   epsg = 4326,   cache = TRUE,   update_cache = FALSE,   cache_dir = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   resolution = 20,   spatialtype = "RG",   country = NULL,   nuts_id = NULL,   nuts_level = c("all", "0", "1", "2", "3"),   ext = "gpkg" )

title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
text: https://gisco-services.ec.europa.eu/distribution/v2/ Copyright: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/administrative-units

title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
text: year character string number. Release year file. One "2024", "2021", "2016", "2013", "2010", "2006", "2003" . epsg character string number. Projection map: 4-digit EPSG code. One : "4326": WGS84 "3035": ETRS89 / ETRS-LAEA "3857": Pseudo-Mercator cache logical. Whether caching. Default TRUE. See Caching strategies section gisco_set_cache_dir(). update_cache logical. cached file refreshed?. Default FALSE. set TRUE force new download. cache_dir character string. path cache directory. See Caching strategies section gisco_set_cache_dir(). verbose logical. TRUE displays informational messages. resolution character string number. Resolution geospatial data. One : "60": 1:60 million. "20": 1:20 million. "10": 1:10 million. "03": 1:3 million. "01": 1:1 million. spatialtype character string. Type geometry returned. Options available : "RG": Regions - MULTIPOLYGON/POLYGON object. "LB": Labels - POINT object. "BN": Boundaries - LINESTRING object. Note arguments country, nuts_level nuts_id applied spatialtype "RG" "LB". country character vector country codes. either vector country names, vector ISO3 country codes vector Eurostat country codes. See also countrycode::countrycode(). nuts_id Optional. character vector NUTS IDs. nuts_level character string. NUTS level. One 0, 1, 2, 3 levels. ext character. Extension file (default "gpkg"). One "shp", "gpkg", "geojson" .

title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts

title: Territorial units for statistics (NUTS) dataset — gisco_get_nuts
text: NUTS nomenclature hierarchical classification statistical regions subdivides EU economic territory regions three different levels (NUTS 1, 2 3, moving respectively larger smaller territorial units). NUTS 1 aggregated level. additional Country level (NUTS 0) also available countries nation statistical level coincide administrative boundaries. NUTS classification officially established Commission Delegated Regulation 2019/1755. non-official NUTS-like classification defined EFTA countries, candidate countries potential candidates based bilateral agreement Eurostat respective statistical agencies. introduction NUTS classification available : https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/nuts/overview.

text: sf object.

title: Urban Audit dataset — gisco_get_urban_audit
text: See Eurostat - Statistics Explained. cities defined several conceptual levels: core city ("CITIES"), using administrative definition. Functional Urban Area/Large Urban Zone ("FUA"), approximating functional urban region. coverage EU plus Iceland, Norway Switzerland . dataset includes polygon features, point features related attribute table can joined URAU code field. "URAU_CATG" field defines Urban Audit category: "C" = City. "F" = Functional Urban Area Service Type.

title: NUTS 2024 sf object — gisco_nuts_2024
text: dataset represents regions levels 0, 1, 2 3 Nomenclature Territorial Units Statistics (NUTS) 2024.

title: NUTS 2024 sf object — gisco_nuts_2024
text: sf object MULTIPOLYGON geometries, resolution: 1:20 million EPSG:4326. 263 rows 10 variables: NUTS_ID NUTS identifier. LEVL_CODE NUTS level code (0,1,2,3). CNTR_CODE Eurostat Country code. NAME_LATN NUTS name Latin characters. NUTS_NAME NUTS name local alphabet. MOUNT_TYPE Mount Type, see Details. URBN_TYPE Urban Type, see Details. COAST_TYPE Coast Type, see Details. geo NUTS_ID, provided compatibility eurostat. geometry geometry field.

title: NUTS 2024 sf object — gisco_nuts_2024
text: NUTS_RG_20M_2024_4326.gpkg file.

title: NUTS 2024 sf object — gisco_nuts_2024
text: MOUNT_TYPE: Mountain typology: 1: 50 % surface covered topographic mountain areas. 2: 50 % regional population lives topographic mountain areas. 3: 50 % surface covered topographic mountain areas 50 % regional population lives mountain areas. 4: Non-mountain region / regions. 0: classification provided. URBN_TYPE: Urban-rural typology: 1: Predominantly urban region. 2: Intermediate region. 3: Predominantly rural region. 0: classification provided. COAST_TYPE: Coastal typology: 1: Coastal (coast). 2: Coastal (less 50% population living within 50 km. coastline). 3: Non-coastal region. 0: classification provided.

title: Set your giscoR cache dir — gisco_set_cache_dir
text: files can read online source without caching using option cache = FALSE. Otherwise source file downloaded computer. giscoR implements following caching options: occasional use, rely default tempdir()-based cache (install). Modify cache single session setting gisco_set_cache_dir(cache_dir = "/path/). reproducible workflows, install persistent cache gisco_set_cache_dir(cache_dir = "/path/, install = TRUE) kept across R sessions. caching specific files, use cache_dir argument corresponding function. See example gisco_get_nuts(). Sometimes cached files may corrupt. case, try re-downloading data setting update_cache = TRUE corresponding function. experience problem download, try download corresponding file method save cache_dir. Use option verbose = TRUE debugging API query gisco_detect_cache_dir() identify cached path.

title: Set your giscoR cache dir — gisco_set_cache_dir
code: # Don't run this! It would modify your current state # \dontrun{ my_cache <- gisco_detect_cache_dir() #> ℹ C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/giscoR  # Set an example cache ex <- file.path(tempdir(), "example", "cachenew") gisco_set_cache_dir(ex) #> ℹ giscoR cache dir is C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/example/cachenew. #> ℹ To install your `cache_dir` path for use in future sessions run this function with `install = TRUE`.  gisco_detect_cache_dir() #> ℹ C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/example/cachenew #> [1] "C:\\Users\\RUNNER~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\Rtmpc3gjgJ/example/cachenew"  # Restore initial cache gisco_set_cache_dir(my_cache) #> ℹ giscoR cache dir is C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/giscoR. #> ℹ To install your `cache_dir` path for use in future sessions run this function with `install = TRUE`. identical(my_cache, gisco_detect_cache_dir()) #> ℹ C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/giscoR #> [1] TRUE # }   gisco_detect_cache_dir() #> ℹ C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpc3gjgJ/giscoR #> [1] "C:\\Users\\RUNNER~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\Rtmpc3gjgJ/giscoR"

title: giscoR (development version)
text: major release introduces full overhaul codebase test suite. Requests now use httr2, GeoPackage (”gpkg”) becomes preferred download format available. Cached files reorganized topic-based subfolders easier management. internal changes, existing caches compatible release must rebuilt. Database management also improved. Instead relying static ?gisco_db dataset, package now stores database cache. cached database used API calls can updated via gisco_get_cached_db(update_cache = TRUE). practice, means GISCO publishes new yearly release, can access new updated data simply refreshing cached database without waiting new version giscoR. transitioned rappdirs::user_config_dir() tools::R_user_dir() managing persistent cache directory. heavy giscoR user already cache directory place, ’ll receive one-time friendly message informing migration. Consider warm welcome giscoR 1.0.0 😉. package now requires R ≥ 4.1, dependency updates improve performance maintainability. functions return tidy objects (tibbles sf objects tibble data). Dataset subsetting now performed read time using GDAL’s query capabilities (sf::read_sf()), improving performance reducing file size. geojsonsf dependency longer required. Several new functions arguments added, functions renamed, one deprecated. bundled datasets updated latest versions. recommend reviewing updated documentation https://ropengov.github.io/giscoR/.

title: giscoR (development version)
text: Refactor code test suite improved stability. Switch API requests httr2. Adopt GeoPackage (”gpkg”) preferred download format. Reorganize cache topic-based subfolders. Note: Previous caches must recreated.
